comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The V.R. sign might help identify exactly which gun position this was. There are several all over Middle Head and Georges Heights - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Sydney+NSW&hl=en&ll=-33...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmm harder than I first thought! The SLNSW has another Bayliss photo in which this gun appears to feature, and you can just make out a sign to the left that would read 'No ? Gun', as in this Henry King pic where a sign reading 'No. 1 Gun' is visible'. Perhaps you can make out the number with your super-sleuth eyes?!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] NLA also has a copy of the SLNSW photo, in better nic too! - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.pic-vn4236860. It was published in Ennis' Bayliss book - A Modern Vision: Charles Bayliss, Photographer, 1850–1897 [PDF, 2.73 MB]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] That is the problem with the old (and sometimes new) photos of these various forts - they are often mis-named, like the NLA and Ennis book both say "Middle Head", when it is obviously Georges Head from the alignment of South and North Heads (see the GoogleSatellite photo).  Very confusing, and it gets perpetuated.  Btw the best way to see is with the GoogleEarth plugin and the 3D enabled.

In a previous existence I was a "dish-pig" at the old Officers Mess behind this battery, and used to wander all over it in my tea-break.  The tunnels and underground rooms were very spooky!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Best way to get to know them by the sounds of it :) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks Pelle, thats easier to get a good look at.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Excellent 1877 interactive map showing the positions of the various gun emplacements (obviously does not show later alterations) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm1400-sd&rgn=...
